title: Entomology
description:
The scientific study of insects, including their biology and ecology.
Example: Study of insects

title: Insect Morphology
description:
The study of the structure and form of insect bodies.
Example: Insect anatomy

title: Insect Taxonomy
description:
The classification of insects based on their characteristics.
Example: Insect classification

title: Arthropoda
description:
A phylum that includes insects, crustaceans, and arachnids.
Example: Insects and crustaceans

title: Hexapoda
description:
A subphylum of Arthropoda that includes insects and their relatives.
Example: Springtails and insects

title: Insecta
description:
The class of arthropods that includes all insects.
Example: Beetles, butterflies

title: Exoskeleton
description:
A hard outer structure that provides support and protection.
Example: Insect cuticle

title: Chitin
description:
A fibrous substance forming the main component of insect exoskeletons.
Example: Beetle shell

title: Head
description:
The foremost body segment containing eyes, antennae, and mouthparts.
Example: Ant head

title: Thorax
description:
The middle body segment, which bears the legs and wings.
Example: Butterfly thorax

title: Abdomen
description:
The posterior segment of the body that houses digestive and reproductive organs.
Example: Bee abdomen

title: Compound Eyes
description:
Large multifaceted visual organs found in most insects.
Example: Fly vision

title: Ocelli
description:
Simple light-sensitive eyes found in some insects.
Example: Spider eyes

title: Antennae
description:
Sensory appendages on the head used for detecting stimuli.
Example: Moth antennae

title: Mandibles
description:
Paired mouthparts used for cutting and chewing food.
Example: Ant mandibles

title: Proboscis
description:
A tubular mouthpart adapted for sucking nectar and other fluids.
Example: Butterfly proboscis

title: Maxillae
description:
Paired appendages used for manipulating food.
Example: Grasshopper maxillae

title: Labium
description:
A lower lip-like structure that assists in food manipulation.
Example: Fly labium

title: Wings
description:
Paired structures used for flight in most insects.
Example: Dragonfly wings

title: Elytra
description:
Hardened forewings of beetles that protect the hindwings.
Example: Beetle elytra

title: Haltere
description:
Modified hindwings in Diptera used for balance during flight.
Example: Fly halteres

title: Metamorphosis
description:
A developmental transformation that insects undergo.
Example: Butterfly life cycle

title: Complete Metamorphosis
description:
A four-stage life cycle: egg, larva, pupa, and adult.
Example: Beetle development

title: Incomplete Metamorphosis
description:
A three-stage life cycle: egg, nymph, and adult.
Example: Grasshopper development

title: Larva
description:
The worm-like juvenile stage in holometabolous insects.
Example: Caterpillar stage

title: Pupa
description:
The inactive, non-feeding developmental stage before adulthood.
Example: Butterfly pupa

title: Nymph
description:
An immature stage in hemimetabolous insects, resembling the adult.
Example: Cockroach nymph

title: Instar
description:
A developmental stage between molts in immature insects.
Example: Grasshopper instar

title: Molting
description:
The shedding of the exoskeleton to allow growth.
Example: Cricket molting

title: Ecdysis
description:
The process of shedding the old exoskeleton.
Example: Ant molting

title: Chrysalis
description:
A protective covering formed by butterfly pupae.
Example: Butterfly chrysalis

title: Cocoon
description:
A silk case spun by moth larvae to protect pupae.
Example: Silkworm cocoon

title: Diapause
description:
A period of suspended development in response to environmental conditions.
Example: Ladybug diapause

title: Oviposition
description:
The process of egg-laying in insects.
Example: Butterfly egg-laying

title: Ootheca
description:
A protective egg case produced by some insects.
Example: Cockroach ootheca

title: Tarsus
description:
The last segment of an insect’s leg.
Example: Fly tarsus

title: Coxa
description:
The basal segment of an insect’s leg.
Example: Grasshopper coxa

title: Femur
description:
The thickest segment of the insect leg.
Example: Beetle femur

title: Tibia
description:
A leg segment between the femur and tarsus.
Example: Ant tibia

title: Entognatha
description:
A group of wingless primitive hexapods.
Example: Springtail

title: Ectognatha
description:
A group of insects with external mouthparts.
Example: Butterfly

title: Ametabolous
description:
A type of insect development without metamorphosis.
Example: Silverfish

title: Paurometabolous
description:
A type of gradual metamorphosis with multiple nymph stages.
Example: Cockroach nymph

title: Hypermetamorphosis
description:
A complex life cycle with multiple larval forms.
Example: Blister beetle larvae

title: Polyphenism
description:
A phenomenon where insects develop different forms based on environment.
Example: Butterfly morphs

title: Gregarious Phase
description:
A social phase in locusts where they form swarms.
Example: Locust swarm

title: Solitary Phase
description:
A non-social phase in locusts where they live alone.
Example: Solitary locust

title: Apterygota
description:
A subclass of wingless primitive insects.
Example: Bristletail

title: Pterygota
description:
A subclass of winged or secondarily wingless insects.
Example: Dragonfly

title: Neoptera
description:
A division of insects that can fold their wings.
Example: Beetles

title: Exopterygota
description:
Insects with external wing development.
Example: Grasshopper

title: Endopterygota
description:
Insects with internal wing development.
Example: Butterfly

title: Insect Cuticle
description:
The outermost layer of the insect body.
Example: Insect exoskeleton

title: Sclerotization
description:
The process of hardening the insect cuticle.
Example: Beetle shell

title: Hemolymph
description:
The circulatory fluid of insects.
Example: Insect blood

title: Tracheal System
description:
A network of tubes used for insect respiration.
Example: Grasshopper breathing

title: Spiracle
description:
An opening in the body for breathing.
Example: Caterpillar spiracle

title: Malpighian Tubules
description:
Excretory organs in insects that remove waste.
Example: Bee excretion

title: Fat Body
description:
A tissue in insects involved in metabolism and storage.
Example: Cockroach fat body

title: Insect Brain
description:
The central nervous organ controlling insect functions.
Example: Ant brain

title: Ganglia
description:
Clusters of nerve cells controlling movement.
Example: Cricket nerve

title: Sensilla
description:
Sensory organs detecting environmental stimuli.
Example: Butterfly sensilla

title: Tympanal Organ
description:
A hearing organ in insects like crickets.
Example: Moth ear

title: Johnston’s Organ
description:
A sensory organ in insect antennae.
Example: Mosquito antenna

title: Ovipositor
description:
A specialized organ for laying eggs.
Example: Grasshopper ovipositor

title: Insect Courtship
description:
Behaviors related to mate attraction in insects.
Example: Firefly flashing

title: Swarming
description:
A large gathering of insects for reproduction.
Example: Mayfly swarm

title: Trophallaxis
description:
Exchange of food or fluids among colony members.
Example: Ant food exchange

title: Social Insects
description:
Insects that live in cooperative colonies.
Example: Termite colony

title: Colony Collapse Disorder
description:
A disorder causing mass disappearance of bees.
Example: Bee disappearance

title: Insect Navigation
description:
The ability of insects to find their way.
Example: Butterfly navigation

title: Magnetoreception
description:
The ability to detect Earth's magnetic field.
Example: Monarch magnetoreception

title: Eusociality
description:
The highest level of social organization in insects.
Example: Bee eusociality

title: Worker Caste
description:
A sterile female caste responsible for labor.
Example: Ant worker

title: Queen Caste
description:
A reproductive female caste in insect colonies.
Example: Bee queen

title: Drone Caste
description:
A male reproductive caste in insect colonies.
Example: Drone bee

title: Insect Parasites
description:
Insects that parasitize other organisms.
Example: Flea

title: Kleptoparasitism
description:
A form of parasitism where insects steal food.
Example: Cuckoo wasp

title: Insect Symbiosis
description:
Mutualistic relationships between insects and other species.
Example: Beetle symbiosis

title: Myrmecophytes
description:
Plants that have mutualistic relationships with ants.
Example: Acacia tree

title: Termitarium
description:
A nest structure built by termites.
Example: Termite nest

title: Silk Production
description:
The production of silk by insects like silkworms.
Example: Silkworm silk

title: Insect Venom
description:
Toxic substances secreted by certain insects.
Example: Wasp venom

title: Insect Pollination Efficiency
description:
The effectiveness of insects in transferring pollen.
Example: Bee pollination

title: Insect Migration
description:
Seasonal or long-distance movement of insects.
Example: Monarch migration

title: Ecological Role of Insects
description:
The role insects play in ecosystems.
Example: Dung beetle decomposition

title: Chitin
description:
A structural polysaccharide forming insect exoskeletons.
Example: Beetle exoskeleton

title: Elytra
description:
The hardened forewings of beetles that protect hindwings.
Example: Ladybug elytra

title: Hemimetabolous
description:
Incomplete metamorphosis with nymphs resembling adults.
Example: Grasshopper nymph

title: Holometabolous
description:
Complete metamorphosis with distinct larval and pupal stages.
Example: Butterfly life cycle

title: Metamorphosis
description:
A biological process of developmental transformation.
Example: Moth metamorphosis

title: Instar
description:
A growth stage between molts in insect development.
Example: Caterpillar instar

title: Diapause
description:
A period of suspended development in response to environmental conditions.
Example: Mosquito diapause

title: Molting
description:
The shedding of the exoskeleton for growth.
Example: Cricket molting

title: Ecdysis
description:
The process of shedding the cuticle.
Example: Spider shedding

title: Pheromones
description:
Chemical signals used for communication within a species.
Example: Ant trail pheromones

title: Kairomones
description:
Chemical signals benefiting a receiver from another species.
Example: Mosquito kairomones

title: Allomones
description:
Chemical signals that benefit the sender but harm the receiver.
Example: Stink bug secretion

title: Bioluminescence
description:
The ability of certain insects to produce light.
Example: Firefly light

title: Mimicry
description:
Resembling another organism to avoid predation.
Example: Hoverfly mimicry

title: Crypsis
description:
Camouflage used to blend into the environment.
Example: Walking stick insect

title: Batesian Mimicry
description:
A harmless species mimicking a harmful one.
Example: Coral snake mimic

title: Müllerian Mimicry
description:
Two harmful species evolving similar warning signals.
Example: Monarch-Viceroy mimicry

title: Thanatosis
description:
Feigning death as a defensive mechanism.
Example: Possum beetle

title: Defensive Secretions
description:
Substances secreted for defense against predators.
Example: Bombardier beetle

title: Autohemorrhaging
description:
Exuding blood as a defense mechanism.
Example: Bleeding moth

title: Aposematism
description:
Bright coloration warning of toxicity.
Example: Poison dart frog mimic

title: Stridulation
description:
Sound production by rubbing body parts.
Example: Cricket chirping

title: Luciferin
description:
A molecule involved in insect bioluminescence.
Example: Firefly luciferin

title: Luciferase
description:
An enzyme involved in insect bioluminescence.
Example: Glow-worm luciferase

title: Insecticide Resistance
description:
Genetic adaptation allowing survival against insecticides.
Example: Mosquito insecticide resistance

title: Integrated Pest Management
description:
A sustainable pest control approach combining multiple methods.
Example: Crop pest management

title: Biocontrol
description:
Using natural enemies to control pest populations.
Example: Ladybug controlling aphids

title: Pollination Syndrome
description:
Traits that attract specific pollinators.
Example: Bee pollination

title: Forensic Entomology
description:
Using insects to determine time of death in forensic cases.
Example: Blowfly forensic use

title: Medical Entomology
description:
The study of insects affecting human health.
Example: Mosquito-borne diseases
